snippet: Most of the political changes that fueled the fight of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-appointed caliph of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, were born directly from some American action.
abstract: Rise of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, self-appointed caliph of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, has been shaped by United States involvement in Iraq at every turn; most of political changes that fueled his fight to redraw map of Middle East, or led to his promotion, were born directly from some American action.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Baghdad, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Omar al-Jawoshy contributed reporting from Baghdad; Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon; and Karam Shoumali from Istanbul.

lead_paragraph: Most of the political changes that fueled the fight of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-appointed caliph of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, were born directly from some American action.

headline.seo: Baghdadi of ISIS Pushes an Islamist Crusade
headline.main: U.S. Actions in Iraq Fueled Rise of a Rebel
headline.print_headline: U.S. Actions in Iraq Fueled Rise of a Rebel
